headline.main: Diet Pill Was a Driving Force in a French Drug Merger

docs.abstract: French drug company Sanofi-Synthelabo's acquisition of French-German rival Aventis linked to Sanofi's new drug rimonabant, which will be marketed as Acomplia, that fights obesity and smoking; drug was in Sanofi's pipeline long before merger of company, now called Sanofi-Aventis; analysts and doctors say drug could become one of industry's once-in-a-decade blockbusters; Sanofi plans to file for regulatory approval early next year in US and Europe; hopes to put drug on market in 2006; Sanofi needed Aventis's powerful sales force to market drug; photo (M)

byline.original: By MARK LANDLER; Denise Grady contributed reporting for this article

docs.lead_paragraph: The year's big drug-industry merger may turn out to be about using marketing muscle to fight fat. In April, when the French drug company Sanofi-Synthélabo vanquished all other players with a long-shot takeover bid for a much larger French-German rival, Aventis, many commentators focused on the role of politicians in Paris.
docs.snippet: The year's big drug-industry merger may turn out to be about using marketing muscle to fight fat.

headline.main: Clinton Is Given Bypass Surgery For 4 Arteries

docs.abstract: Former Pres Clinton undergoes successful quadruple coronary bypass surgery at New York-Presbyterian Hospital in Manhattan; doctors say he is resting comfortably afterward and is expected to make complete recovery; four-hour open-heart procedure by team of surgeons is led by Dr Craig R Smith, hospital's chief of cardio-thoracic surgery; Dr Allan Schwartz, hospital's chief of cardiology, says that without bypass surgery, there was 'substantial likelihood' that Clinton would have had serious heart attack in near future; Schwartz, Smith and other doctors attending post-operation press conference say that Clinton's heart muscle is strong and with proper diet and other precautions he could resume active life within weeks and could look forward to normal lifespan; he turned 58 on Aug 19; 45,000 calls, letters and messages of support pour into hospital and to Web site; Sen Hillary Rodham Clinton and daughter Chelsea express gratitude to medical team and staff at hospital; photo (M)

byline.original: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN and LAWRENCE K. ALTMAN

docs.lead_paragraph: Former President Bill Clinton, a cigar-smoking workaholic whose family history of heart disease and passion for junk food had set him up for a heart attack in the near future, underwent successful quadruple coronary bypass surgery yesterday at a hospital in New York, his doctors said. They said Mr. Clinton was resting comfortably afterward and was expected to make a complete recovery.
docs.snippet: Former President Bill Clinton, a workaholic with a passion for junk food, underwent successful quadruple bypass surgery.

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-13 Top China Leader Says He May Step Down Jiang Zemin, China's military chief and senior leader, has told Communist Party officials that he plans to resign, prompting an intense and so far inconclusive struggle for control of the armed forces, two people with leadership connections say. Mr. Jiang's offer potentially gives President Hu Jintao a chance to become the country's undisputed leader. A1 Car Bomb Kills 10 in Iraq A car bomb tore through a convoy of American and Iraqi troops near Falluja, killing seven marines and three Iraqis in the single deadliest attack on American troops in four months, American military officials said. Al Jazeera, the Arab news network, reported that an Islamic militant group holding two French hostages had given a list of demands including a ransom of $5 million and had issued a 48-hour deadline. A12
